Comment: The thing to know is that oftentimes these contests aren't even opposed. Most local school boards, especially in rural or smaller areas, struggle with finding members willing and able to serve. Once on the Board, they may rarely face challengers at all, let alone serious competition.  So you sometimes end up with crazy boards, because that's who volunteers.  Then, as long as your district can avoid the spotlight, you can probably serve as long as you want. However, if your district is thrust into some controversy, you'll probably face challengers for the first time in your tenure. And voters tend to dislike controversial Boards - both on the Left and the Right.   I'd be a bit wary of deriving a pattern from one or two elections in a highly publicized school district. But, if we start to see a one-sided trend, that would send a signal to both other school boards and the political interests watching that this policy is a loser at the ballot box.
